data.title: Repeaters
data.meta_description: In amateur radio, an electronic device that receives a weak or low-level amateur radio signal and retransmits it at a higher level or higher power, so that the signal can cover longer distances...
data.text:
What is a repeater?

In amateur radio, an electronic device that receives a weak or low-level amateur radio signal and retransmits it at a higher level or higher power, so that the signal can cover longer distances without degradation. Often times these repeaters are centrally located within an area to provide quality communications.

N8IHI VHF Repeater- Widowville

147.105 +0.6kz PL 71.9

This repeater is located just South of U.S. 30 on State Route 511. This repeater is a an Icom 5000 repeater. This site is used for primary communications and activated for ARES and Skywarn in the event of those needs. The AAARC weekly net is hosted on this repeater every Thursday at 7:30pm EST

***During local events we commonly utilize 147.055 simplex for local event ops to keep from typing up this repeater***

N8IHI UHF Repeater- Ashland

444.0375 +5.0 mhz PL 71.9/ Color Code 7

This repeater is dual mode, analog and DMR with primary use as DMR.

This repeater is located Northeast of Ashland at the intersection of County Road 1302 and Township Road 653. This is a Hytera UHF 20 watt repeater. It is connected to the Brandmeister Network. Scroll below for Talkgroup information.

W3YXS VHF Repeater- Loudonville

146.745 -0.6kz PL 71.9

This repeater is located in Loudonville. It is at the FM radio Station, WZLP. This repeater provides excellent coverage to the Mohican State Park region, including Perrysville, Loudonville, and Clear Fork Valley.

Other Ashland County Repeaters

N8SIW VHF 145.130 -0.6kz PL 110.9, wide area coverage on linked system

N8SIW UHF 442.975 +5.0mhz PL 131.8, wide area coverage on linked system

KA8VDW UHF 443.625 +5.0mhz PL 162.2, has emergency power with excellent coverage

​WA8TJC UHF 442.150 +5.0 PL 88.5

03 VTAC 146.430

03UTAC 446.400
